Claviceps purpurea 20.1 is a fungal species that belongs to the genus Claviceps. It is a plant pathogen known for its ability to infect cereal crops, particularly rye, wheat, and barley. The species is characterized by the formation of dark, elongated structures called sclerotia, which replace the grains of the infected plants.

The sclerotia of Claviceps purpurea 20.1 contain a variety of ergot alkaloids, including ergotamine, ergocristine, and ergocryptine. These alkaloids have potent pharmacological effects on the human nervous system and can cause a condition known as ergot poisoning or ergotism when consumed in contaminated grains.

Claviceps purpurea 20.1 is an important plant pathogen that can have significant economic and health implications for agriculture and food production. Its study is crucial for understanding the biology and management of this fungal species, as well as the potential therapeutic applications of the ergot alkaloids it produces.
